title: 105_s620
content: The "Women's Investment and Savings Equity Act of 1997" allows individuals to make deductible IRA contributions without considering their spouse's participation in a pension plan. Additionally, individuals can contribute during periods of maternity or paternity leave. The amendment allows participants on maternity or paternity leave to make additional elective deferrals under their plan or arrangement. The amendment allows participants on maternity or paternity leave to make additional elective deferrals under their plan or arrangement without being subject to certain contribution limitations. The amendment permits participants on maternity or paternity leave to make extra elective deferrals under their plan without facing contribution limitations related to specific sections of the tax code. Matching contributions are not required but if made, separate requirements apply. The amendment allows participants on maternity or paternity leave to make additional elective deferrals without contribution limitations. Matching contributions, if made, are subject to separate requirements. Employees on eligible maternity or paternity leave can make additional elective deferrals without contribution limitations. These deferrals can be made within 3 years after the leave ends, with proper adjustments for any deferrals made during the leave period. Matching contributions, if any, are subject to separate requirements. Employees on eligible maternity or paternity leave can make additional elective deferrals without contribution limitations. The matching contribution for such deferrals must be made by the employer's tax return due date. Eligible maternity or paternity leave includes absences due to pregnancy, childbirth, adoption, or caring for a child. Employees on eligible maternity or paternity leave can make additional elective deferrals without contribution limitations for up to 12 months after the birth or placement of a child. The term 'elective deferral' includes after-tax employee contributions, and the term 'plan' encompasses arrangements under section 408(k) or (p). Certain retroactive adjustments are not required, and loan repayment suspensions are permitted for applicable plans or arrangements. The rules of subsection (u)(4) apply to loan repayment suspensions during eligible maternity and paternity leave starting after December 31, 1997. Catchup contributions are allowed for families with children not covered by a pension plan. Catchup contributions for families with children not covered by a pension plan are permitted under certain conditions in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes provisions for additional elective deferrals in eligible plans or arrangements. Catchup contributions allow eligible participants to make additional elective deferrals in certified catchup years, limited to 120 percent of the applicable dollar limitation. The contribution to a plan under paragraph (1) is not subject to certain limitations for the year it is made. The contribution to a plan under paragraph (1) is exempt from specific limitations for the year it is made, and the plan will not fail to meet certain requirements due to this contribution. Matching contributions are not required for additional elective deferrals under paragraph (1) for any year. Matching contributions for additional elective deferrals under paragraph (1) are subject to separate application of section 401(a)(4) requirements. The amount of such matching contributions cannot exceed the maximum allowed under the plan for elective deferrals made in that year. Participants must certify to the plan administrator when making additional elective deferrals. An eligible participant may certify one or more years as catchup years, with a limit on the total number of certified years. Plans are not responsible for certification failures. An eligible participant can certify certain years as catch-up years, with a limit on the total number of certified years. Plans are not held accountable for certification errors unless the plan administrator was aware or should have been aware of the inaccuracy. The term "eligible participant" refers to a participant in a plan who was not an active participant for any plan year preceding the current year and had a child under 18 for whom a deduction was allowed. The amendment made by this section allows for deductions for participants aged 18 or with a child under 18. The effective date is for contributions in taxable years beginning after December 31, 1997.
